repnme.cdata!: West Bank and Gaza - Solid Waste Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This results profile talks about the
            Solid Waste and Environmental Management Project in West
            Bank and Gaza. Drawing on World Bank Group financing and
            expertise since 2001, the Palestinians were able to improve
            solid waste management and environmental conditions in 80
            communities in Jenin Governorate, with a population of
            200,000 people. They achieved this by establishing a new
            sanitary landfill, closing and rehabilitating 85 dumpsites,
            and improving waste collection services. Towards the end of
            the project, the new landfill was expanded to serve all five
            governors that comprises the northern West Bank (population
            600,000), providing for further cost saving and enhancing
            public-private partnerships.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Solid Waste and
            Environmental Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Solid Waste and Environmental
            Management Project for West Bank and Gaza had a highly
            satisfactory outcome and moderate risk to development
            outcome. Both the Bank and the borrower performances were
            satisfactory. The main lessons learned were: (1) in conflict
            situations, it is advisable to seek out and build upon the
            common interests that often exist beneath the heat and
            rhetoric. This can sometimes open up previously unforeseen
            possibilities for cooperation. (2) Local ownership is more
            critical for project success than is often recognized. Local
            ownership is often taken for granted as a self-evident
            prerequisite for project success. (3) Individuals can and do
            make a major difference to project success; thus seeking out
            and strongly supporting capable local professionals is
            advisable. (4) Effective channels of public communication
            and feedback support sustainability and can and should be
            built into project design. (5) Investment in changing the
            culture is often as important as physical investments, and
            sometimes more so: Though difficult to specify before hand
            and often the result of luckas partly in this case - these
            investments make it difficult for a return to bad habits and
            practices and thus strongly support project sustainability.
            (6) SWM can serve as an effective entry point for improving
            municipal management and service delivery: The sector is
            highly visible, often neglected, and the potential negative
            impacts obvious to the public. (7) Early preparation,
            consensus building and learning can pay significant
            dividends. Early investment in donor participation also paid
            significant dividends in later support. The Bank preparation
            teams efforts in bringing in other donors very early in the
            project preparation cycle later helped in burden sharing and
            mobilizing necessary financial and technical support for the
            project. (8) Consistent, thoughtful, and dedicated on-ground
            Bank supervision support can be the difference between
            success and failure.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Solid Waste and
            Environmental Management Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Solid Waste and
            Environmental Management Project for West Bank and Gaza is
            to improve the environmental living conditions of the people
            of Anabta and surrounding villages through an
            environmentally sound solid waste management system.
            Negative measures include: air management; noise management;
            particulates and dust smoke; wastewater management; waste
            management; and hazardous materials management. Mitigation
            measures include: a) ensure that potential air pollutants
            are contained and that activities do not impact on the
            natural environment; b) ensure that operations do not
            generate odour that causes environmental nuisance; c) ensure
            that particulate and dust emissions, both individually and
            cumulatively, meet appropriate criteria and do not cause an
            environmental or human health problem; d) ensure that noise
            and vibration levels meet acceptable standards and that an
            adequate level of service, safety and public amenity is
            maintained; and e) ensure that such wastes are not arriving
            or accepted at the site, unless special measures are taken.

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Solid Waste and
            Environmental Management Project : resettlement plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Solid Waste and
            Environmental Management Project for West Bank and Gaza is
            to improve the environmental living conditions of the people
            of Anabta and surrounding villages through an
            environmentally sound solid waste management system.
            Negative impacts include: loss of income, loss of
            livelihood, loss of employment, and impact on waste picker.
            Mitigation measures include: 1) picking is unhealthy and
            unsafe work and it designates these affected people with a
            social stigma in their society. Therefore, the Wadi Shaer
            Joint Service Council (WSJSC) social committee concerns to
            compensate the waste pickers through alternative work
            opportunities that are safe and financially rewarding; and
            2) waste pickers do not have any legal right on the basis of
            which they can bring a claim for compensation for loss of
            income before a court. That does not mean that they cannot
            try to do so, but it is unlikely that a court will be able
            to assist them. Therefore the social committee is to be set
            up under the WSJSC to hear any concerns/ disputes with waste pickers.

            waste pickers

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Environment and Solid
            Waste Project : environmental assessment (Phase 2)

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the West Bank and Gaza Solid Waste and Environmental
            Management Project (SWEMP), which constructs and operates a
            sanitary waste disposal for two towns and surrounding
            villages. Key negative impacts and corresponding mitigation
            measures follow. A high standard of leachate containment and
            management is a fundamental aspect of the proposed site
            design. The risk of exposure to an explosion of landfill gas
            is minimized through site design which should include
            passive venting and landfill gas monitoring. The potential
            impacts from noise, dust, and odor at the site will be
            minimized by erecting sound barriers, using waste
            compaction, daily covering the landfill site with crushed
            and sorted inert construction waste to prevent prolonged
            exposure of potentially odorous wastes to the atmosphere,
            disallowing open burning on site, damping down roads as well
            as covering material stockpiles and transport vehicles,
            ensuring that all vehicles pass through wheel washes when
            departing from the site, and controlling haulage routes and
            traffic flows and patterns to reduce dust and vehicle
            emissions. Litter impacts can be controlled by operating
            small waste cells and litter screens. Landscaping and buffer
            zone works should be used to provide the maximum possible
            screening of the landfill site. Loss of visual amenity
            during site operation will be corrected by replanting the
            site and allowing it to progressively restore itself.
